Hypenotic The Jekyll Butler

@SlowFoodTO: Leaving a twitter account behind

01 Jun 2011

We learn new lessons every day here. Modern marketing is evolving so quickly that people who don’t develop an iterative approach can really suffer.
But every once in a while you get the chance to explore something that’s worth sinking your teeth into. As it happens, the one that’s had my attention recently was a side-focus. A personal interest. Slow Food.

A guiding interest, to be sure–an interest in food issues is what led Hypenotic to start working with great local brands like the Gladstone Hotel, Fiesta Farms, OCTA, Sustain Ontario, Fifth Town Cheese, Southbrook Vineyards, The Friends of the Greenbelt Foundation, Local Food Plus and others.

I settled on Slow Food because the designer in me was struck by the big hairy challenge of engaging a public blissfully unaware of the danger, inequality, and insufficiency of an unsustainable local food system. Slow Food’s convivial, informative and flavour focuses offered the lowest barrier approach to making people conscious of how their decisions were resulting in unconsidered, undesirable effects. I think it was initially Jodi who coined it ‘a gateway drug to the issues’.

It works pretty simply–eat, talk, share, enjoy. You’re hooked. But like addicts seeking to reproduce the first high, proponents need to dig deeper–change buying habits, meet producers, learn processes, participate, advocate, etc…

I hit the wall recently, though my addiction for participation wasn’t sated. Quite the opposite. I’m escalating. I’ve recently become a member of the Toronto Food Policy Council, as well as a Trustee of the newest Awesome Foundation Chapter–Awesome Food. Rather, I realized that my participation on Slow Food Toronto’s steering committee wasn’t where I could do the most good.

Here’s where the learning/sinking teeth into bit comes in. I’ve been under some pressure to leave my twitter following behind. And I’m going to acquiesce to that pressure, but not without an explanation to the folks who I’ve connected with, and not without some reflection that might benefit others. That’s just how we roll.

There are two sides to considering the appropriate path here. On one hand:

  • The account was called @SlowFoodTO–Slow Food is a trademarked name
  • I told the leader of the convivium (chapter) I was starting the account, did it with his blessing and kept him apprised of progress
  • When we printed cards up, we included the twitter handle
  • There are undoubtedly people who followed it for updates on Slow Food Toronto alone
  • I did this in a volunteer capacity

On the other hand:

  • Twitter isn’t direct mail, and followers aren’t a list–it’s a personal, relationship-based platform
  • I ended up spending more time with it than I expected to (conversations extended from Twitter to Friendfeed and other places)
  • I’m uncomfortable dumping people I’ve built personal relationships with–I’m not a quitter and we started something together
  • I did this in a volunteer capacity (yes, this goes on both lists)

The first list was longer.

In the next few days:

  • @SlowReport will be renamed @SlowFoodToronto
  • Perhaps more importantly, you’ll find Paul DeCampo and Carrie Oliver sharing news there to start, perhaps others soon.
  • I’ll share the food information our research continues to dig up through my personal account @hypenoticbam
  • I’ll continue to promote Slow Values, Initiatives and Slow Food Toronto

Here’s what you should consider before you’re in a similar position.

  • While you’re representing/promoting an entity in a volunteer position, make sure the person you answer to understands the culture of the medium you’re communicating in.
  • Consider if clarifying your relationship is possible–can you use your own name? Variations on the theme can lead to challenges.
  • Treat your contribution like a job–frame out what you’d like to accomplish and what resources you’re prepared to commit to get there.

Thanks, that was fun, and I look forward to connecting in new places.

Barry
